captions.text:
bjbj Episode 14: Earthbound Smile for the
camera and eat some trout yogurt because this

week, we re tackling Mother! Hello Internet.
Welcome to Game Theory, the show where our

special PSI ability is Brainshock. Episode
11, our romp through the Pacific Ocean to

find Adventure Island, got me talking about
my top ten games and this week has me unveiling

one more. Yes, I confess, I am an Earthboundian,
a Ness-o-phile, a Fuzzy-Pickler. Anyway, it

s tied for my number one spot. I mean, what
other game has you fighting ruler-brandishing

hippies, a former member of the ScrewAttack
team, and a huge steaming pile of vomit with

googly eyes? It s a well-loved cult classic
and is hailed as one of the funniest, most

unique games of all time, but this upbeat
Technicolor romp about a boy, his bat, and

the portly demon spawn next door hides a much
darker side. So put on your Mr. Baseball cap

as we check out the birth of the creepiest
boss in gaming, chemical terrorists, police

brutality, prostitutes, dismemberment, and
a whole lot more! In short, this game is like

a transformer, with more than meets the eye.
At first glance, Earthbound simply appears

to be an offbeat RPG with a quirky sense of
humor. Taking place in the year 199X, Ness,

our silent protagonist and psychic wunderkind
(Ryan), along with the help of his motley

crew must save the world from an evil alien
force named Giygas, kinda like Chrono Trigger

but without time travel and replacing the
ethers and crossbows with pizzas and frying

pans. The music sounds like it came from an
episode of Rocko s Modern Life with a lot

of catchy bleeps and blats and the color palette
ranges from Sunday morning comics to psychedelic

trip out. But the Rainbow Brite feel glosses
over some serious issues here. For example,

practically every list chronicling the scariest
bosses in gaming features, spoiler alert,

Earthbound s final fight against Giygas. Which
is odd since no other boss is scarier than

a Hello Kitty stuffed animal. Aw! A giant
ant! A cute disease-ridden rat! But then look

at this! You walk up through a twisted system
of intestines, already a huge change in tone

from the rest of the game, only to fight this
which turns into this The director of the

game, Shigesato Itoi, has been very open in
admitting that his inspiration for Giygas

was what he remembered as a rape scene from
The Military Policeman and the Dismembered

Beauty, an adult movie that traumatized him
when he accidentally saw it as a child. It

also inspired Giygas dialogue, with phrases
like It hurts and I feel good. Also, and I

m just going to touch on this because fans
of the game hate this theory, but it deserves

mentioning: many have debated that the final
boss takes the form of, are you ready for

it? A fetus. Seriously. But it kinda makes
sense, walking along internal organs and then

look at the negative space here. It s like
a messed up Rorschach test. But, baby or no

baby, you can start to see why it s not much
of a stretch to say that Earthbound may have

some darker themes. Take for instance its
cult. And no, I don t mean Earthbound s fanbase.

Sure, the cult depicted in the game calls
itself Happy Happyism. And yes, their mission

statement is laughable considering they figuratively
want to paint the town red by literally painting

it blue which includes coloring the town s
dairy cow a nice shade of periwinkle. But,

like a hallway of fallopian tubes, it gets
a whole lot more disturbing when you look

a little closer. Aum Shinrikyo was a cult
founded in Japan in 1984 by a mostly-blind

acupuncturist who claimed he could levitate.
Here s a copy of their logo and here s an

image of their leader in his traditional attire.
Does the color look familiar? But there s

more. The cult grew in popularity until the
90s when it had built up enough support for

members to run for public office. They didn
t win, but their campaign became synonymous

with singing, dancing, smiling balloons, and
an overall happy tone. Another odd parallel

to the Happyists in Earthbound. But if you
re still not convinced, their headquarters

was located in a small dairy town, a fact
which takes on a new meaning when considering

that the only cow to appear in the game is
the one living right outside the Happy Happyism

compound. So who was this cult? Aum Shinrikyo
began producing the deadly nerve gas serin

in 1993, and used it in the city of Matsumoto,
Nagano killing eight and harming 200, making

it the first instance of terrorism using chemical
weapons against innocent civilians. They struck

again in 1995 on five subway trains in Tokyo.
With baggies of liquefied serin wrapped in

newspapers along with another baggie of solvent
that could turn it into a gas, members of

the cult entered the subways, left the packages,
and then punctured the bags with an umbrella

point on their way out, leaving the deadly
gases to mix behind them, killing 12 and affecting

as many as 5,000. When their compound was
finally raided, investigators found explosives,

anthrax, Ebola, and even a Russian military
helicopter. And knowing this makes a silly

cult wanting to paint the world blue seem
a whole lot more sinister. And the mature

themes don t stop there. What about unprovoked
police brutality? Can you think of another

game released before 1994 with that? How about
a game after 1994? Even in Grand Theft Auto,

the big daddy of bad behavior games, you have
to seriously maim a couple of pedestrians

before the cops will even pay attention to
you! But here, after beating the first boss,

Earthbound has Ness, a young boy, dragged
to the police station where he is assaulted

by four cops and their captain one by one.
It s sick. And accurate. You see, the 90s

as a decade was the first time the phrase
police brutality made it to the public consciousness,

most famously with the case of Rodney King
in 1991. It started when Los Angeles police

officers pulled King over for drunk driving
following a high speed chase. After subduing

him with a taser, the officers proceeded to
kick him repeatedly and hit him 56 times with

their batons. In 1992, a jury acquitted most
of the officers on trial, which led to the

famous LA riots. An interesting story, but
what does it have to do with Earthbound? Well,

remember how I said that Ness defends himself
against four regular cops and their captain?

Guess how many officers were on the scene
during the Rodney King beating. Four and one

sergeant. How about prostitutes leading you
into a hotel room to get mugged? Earthbound

has that. What about willfully choosing to
have your arms, legs, ears, and eyes ripped

from your body, only to then lose your mind?
Earthbound has that too. It s funny how much

an oddball sense of humor and bright tone
can cover up, because as a kid, none of this

made me think twice well, except for that
last test I really didn t want that spirit

guy to rip out my eyes. When Shigesato Itoi
set out to create a different kind of RPG,

one based on the real world, he did just that,
and didn t limit himself to simply replacing

tonics with hamburgers and merchants to department
stores. He dealt with issues you see in the

media every day: rape, religious fanaticism,
violence, but handled them with a dash of

humor and a heaping spoonful of bizarre storytelling.
Earthbound isn t about a boy trying to stop

an alien menace, it s about a boy growing
up, leaving his home and experiencing both

the good and the bad of the world. That s
why Giygas is so scary; he is based on the

moment Itoi lost that childhood innocence.
And that s why the ending is so satisfying,

because Ness faced that darkness and made
it through, becoming a young adult. He s grown

up, and we, as the player, have cared enough
to get him there. It s truly a great game.

But hey, that s just a theory. A Game Theory!

comments.author: KirbyLuigi

comments.text:
+The Game Theorists

I have a theory Mat. A game theory. Mother II or as we know it "Earthbound" 
took place in the year 2000. Think about it. X is the Roman Numeral for 10, 
and the 199 is probably refering to the number 1990 and as 1990>X it means 
you add them. Therefor you get 2000... but then, what if it's simply 
refering to 199? Then it would be the year 209. Or what if it means 19910 
because that's 199 followed by 10? Or what if it's just 1990 because that's 
199 times 10? Hope you make a mini video on this MatPat. But remember, it's 
just a theory... a game theory! Thanks for reading.﻿

comments.text:
I've been part of the Earthbound fan cult since I was very young... six or 
seven years old. I'm twenty-seven now. The memories I made playing this 
game are practically mythical in their remembrance; the music in this game 
could more-or-less function as the soundtrack to my life, so ingrained is 
Earthbound into my consciousness.﻿

comments.text:
You walk into a dark room, scared and confused. A chill goes down your 
spine as a child in a familiar hat and t-shirt whispers "Okey." in your 
ear. You wake up at your home. You don't remember what happened last night, 
or why a copy of Earthbound is sitting on your nightstand.﻿

comments.author: Satoshi Akimoto

comments.text:
I just finished this game for the first time. Let me tell anyone who is 
reading this that hasn't played it, please for the love of god play it. 
You're missing out on so much more than you realize. And this game theory 
is spot on by the way. I have an English translated Gameboy Advance version 
of Mother 1 and 2 and Mother 3 on the way. That's how much I loved this 
unique, amazing, funny, charming game. So worth every hour I put into it. ﻿
